title: How to Diagnose and Treat Scours in Calves

steps.title: Determine if treatment is required.
steps.content: Determine if treatment is required. Calves that are moving around in the pasture, with their tails up, probably do not need treatment. Check to see if the diarrhea is yellow or white. If this is the case, treatment is probably not needed. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Determine if the calf is looking listless.
steps.content: Determine if the calf is looking listless. Calves that are lethargic or not participating much in the playful activities with other calves are a red flag to pay attention to. Calves that are also losing condition are also cause for alarm.

steps.title: Check to see if the calf is dehydrated.
steps.content: Check to see if the calf is dehydrated. You can check for dehydration [3] X Research source by pulling on the calf's neck skin. If the skin "tents" this is a sign of dehydration. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Determine the calf's body temperature.
steps.content: Determine the calf's body temperature. A normal body temperature ranges from 100.5 째F (38.1 째C) to 102.5 째F (39.2 째C). Anything outside of this range is a sign for treatment. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Separate the sick calf or calves from the healthy herd.
steps.content: Separate the sick calf or calves from the healthy herd. You'll want to do this to avoid spreading the disease further. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Administer fluids using your veterinarian-approved electrolyte solution.
steps.content: Administer fluids using your veterinarian-approved electrolyte solution. You may need to inject the fluids via IV or orally. Follow the package directions when mixing up the solution. [7] X Research source Feeding the calf water will not work because it will simply pass through his system and not be completely absorbed. [8] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Follow up with antibiotics if approved by your vet.
steps.content: Follow up with antibiotics if approved by your vet. [9] X Trustworthy Source University of California Division of Agriculture and Natural Resources Extension program of the University of California system devoted to educating and improving local communities Go to source

steps.title: Follow appropriate nursing care protocol using your vet's guidelines.
steps.content: Follow appropriate nursing care protocol using your vet's guidelines. This may include providing shelter, feed, and a warm place to sleep. A drawback of providing shelter is maintaining infectious control. You will have to work extra to get rid of soiled bedding and disinfect everything that a calf will touch, from the floor to the fence panels and even the feed bucket. [10] X Research source
